We show that prolonged treatment with selegiline fails toreduce aberrant astrocytic GABA levels and rescue memory impairment in APP/PS1 mice,an animal model of AD, because of increased activity in compensatory genes for a GABAsynthesizing enzyme, diamine oxidase (DAO). Mutual synergism between cMET and EGFR is known to promote acquireddrug resistance. cMET activation either by gene amplification or mutation has been observed inNSCLC patients with intrinsic or acquired resistance to EGFR inhibitors. Conversely, activationof EGFR was reported as a cause of acquired resistance to cMET inhibitors. Because of thiscrosstalk between cMET and EGFR pathways, dual inhibition of these targets holds promiseas a treatment for NSCLC patients. CKD-702 is a bispecific antibody designed to dually targetcMET and EGFR. CKD-702 binds to extracellular domains of cMET and EGFR with high affinityand inhibits their signaling by blocking ligand binding, degrading and internalizing bothreceptors. CKD-702 significantly inhibits tumor growth in models where cMET is activated byeither skipping of exon 14 or amplification. Also, CKD-702 shows strong anti-tumor activity asa monotherapy in tumor models that have primary/secondary activating EGFR mutations andcMET amplification. This profile of preclinical data supports the clinical trial of CKD-702 as amonotherapy in selected lung cancer patients with aberrant cMET and EGFR signaling.
